{{Infobox civilian attack | title = Ohio State University attack | partof = [[terrorism in the United States]] | image = File:Ohio State Attacks 2016 Police Response, view from Curl Market.jpg | caption = Police presence on the OSU campus, view from Curl Market | location = [[Ohio State University]], [[Columbus, Ohio]], U.S. | date = {{start date|2016|11|28}} | time = 9:52{{nbsp}}a.m.<ref name="ABC.Dead">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/ohio-state-university-student-dead-driving-crowd-stabbing/story?id=43821371|title=Ohio State University Student Dead After Driving Into Crowd, Stabbing People at OSU Campus|publisher=ABC News|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016|first1=Emily|last1=Shapiro|first2=Aaron|last2=Katersky|first3=Josh|last3=Margolin|first4=Mike|last4=Levine}}</ref> | timezone = [[Eastern Time Zone|EST]] | type = Mass stabbing, vehicular assault | weapons = *[[Butcher knife]] *[[Honda Civic]]<ref name="CNN.Attack" /> | fatalities = 1 (perpetrator) | injuries = 13 (11 directly, 1 by stray gunfire, 1 unknown injury) | perp = Abdul Razak Ali Artan | coordinates = {{coord|40.003198|N|83.010850|W}} | motive =[[Islamist terrorism]] inspired by terrorist propaganda<ref name="CNN.Inspired">{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/11/29/us/ohio-state-university-attack/|title=Investigators believe Ohio State attacker was inspired by ISIS|work=CNN|date=November 29, 2016|accessdate=November 29, 2016|first1=Max|last1=Blau|first2=Emanuella|last2=Grinberg|first3=Shimon|last3=Prokupecz}}</ref> }}
On November 28, 2016, a terrorist [[Vehicle-ramming attack|vehicle-ramming]] and [[Stabbing as a terrorist tactic|stabbing attack]] occurred at 9:52{{nbsp}}a.m. EST at [[Ohio State University|Ohio State University's]] [[Watts Hall]] in [[Columbus, Ohio]]. The attacker, [[Somalia|Somali]] refugee Abdul Razak Ali Artan, was shot and killed by the first responding OSU police officer, and 13 people were hospitalized for injuries.
Authorities began investigating the possibility of the attack being an act of terrorism. On the next day, law enforcement officials stated that Artan was inspired by terrorist propaganda from the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL) and the late radical Muslim cleric [[Anwar al-Awlaki]]. [[Amaq News Agency]] released a statement claiming the attacker responded to an ISIL call to attack [[Military intervention against ISIL#International coalitions against ISIL|coalition]] citizens, though there is no evidence of direct contact between the group and Artan.
== Background == There had been high concerns from federal law enforcement officials about [[Car ramming attack|car ramming]] and [[stabbing]] attacks being encouraged by online extremist propaganda due to the relative ease of committing them compared to bombings.<ref name="CBS.Known"/> In the weeks prior to the incident, ISIL had been urging its followers to copy [[2016 Nice attack|a car ramming attack]] in [[Nice]], France, that killed 86 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://abc7chicago.com/news/officials-investigating-anti-us-facebook-rant-believed-linked-to-osu-attacker/1629153/|title=Officials Investigating Anti-US Facebook Rant Believed Linked to OSU Attacker|publisher=WLS-TV|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016|quote=The attack comes as the ISIS terror group has been urging its followers in recent weeks to copy the vehicle attack that took place in Nice, France, when 84 people were killed by a terrorist driving a semi-truck through a Bastille Day celebration.}}</ref>
Earlier that year in February, a man [[2016 Ohio machete attack|attacked patrons at the Nazareth Restaurant]] in [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]], wounding four before being shot and killed by responding police officers. About seven months later, [[2016 Minnesota mall stabbing|a mass stabbing]] occurred at the [[Crossroads Center (St. Cloud, Minnesota)|Crossroads Center]] shopping mall in [[St. Cloud, Minnesota]]. During the attack, a Somali refugee stabbed and injured nearly a dozen people before also being fatally shot by police. Both incidents are currently being investigated as possible acts of terrorism.<ref name="USA.Identified"/><ref name="ColumbusDispatch.Sorting">{{cite web|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/public/2016/osu-attack/fbi-local-law-officers-sorting-out-ohio-state-attackers-tie-to-isis-victims-names-released.html|title=FBI, local officers sorting out Ohio State attacker's tie to ISIS; victims' names released|work=The Columbus Dispatch|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016|first=Beth|last=Burger}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/public/2016/osu-attack/ohio-state-attack-terrorism-cases-in-central-ohio.html|title=Terrorism cases from the past 12 years in central Ohio|work=The Columbus Dispatch|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016}}</ref> There had also been a number of recently foiled ISIL-inspired terror plots or intents to travel to the [[Middle East]] to fight for ISIL, in which the perpetrators all originated from Ohio.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/campus-attack-could-latest-terror-case-heartland-state-143322874.html?ref=gs|title=Campus attack could be latest terror case in heartland state|publisher=Yahoo! News|agency=Associated Press|date=December 3, 2016|accessdate=December 3, 2016|first1=John|last1=Seewer|first2=Dan|last2=Sewell}}</ref>
In the week prior to the attack, the perpetrator, [[#Perpetrator|Abdul Razak Ali Artan]], traveled to [[Washington, D.C.]], and purchased a knife at a [[The Home Depot|Home Depot]] there. The day before the attack, Artan bought a second knife at a [[Walmart]] in Columbus. Investigators have not determined whether either knife was used in the attack, but were particularly suspicious of Artan traveling to the U.S. capital, roughly {{convert|400|mi}} from Columbus by car, to buy a knife.<ref name="NBC.Bought"/>
== Attack == [[File:The courtyard outside Watts Hall.jpg|thumb|The courtyard outside Watts Hall, where the attack took place]] [[File:Silver Honda Civic sedan (2000).jpg|thumb|right|An identical silver Honda Civic, involved in the terror attack]] According to the chairman of the OSU Department of Materials Science and Engineering headquartered at [[Watts Hall]], students told him that someone called in a [[fluorine]] leak in the building, which has lab facilities. As required during emergencies, the students congregated in the courtyard outside the building. At 9:52{{nbsp}}a.m.,<ref name="ABC.Dead"/> the attacker drove a [[Honda Civic]] into the courtyard, deliberately striking several pedestrians, including [[Emeritus|emeritus professor]] William Clark,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/injured-ohio-state-professor-withholding-judgment-student-attacker/story?id=43850613 |title=Injured Professor Says Won't Judge OSU Attacker: 'I'm Going Home ... He's Dead' |first=Emily |last=Shapiro |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=November 29, 2016 |quote=OSU Professor William Clark suffered injuries to his ankle and leg when an OSU student, identified by authorities as Abdul Razak Ali Artan, plowed his car into a crowd, then slashed multiple people on campus Monday morning. |accessdate=November 29, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/public/2016/osu-attack/Ohio-State-victims-update.html |title=Victim of Ohio State attack didn't realize he'd been injured |publisher=''[[The Columbus Dispatch]]'' |date=November 29, 2016 |first1=Danae |last1=King |first2=Holly |last2=Zachariah |quote=Clark recalled being outside Watts Hall with students and other faculty after a report of a gas leak caused the building to be evacuated. When Artan's Honda hit Clark, he flipped into the air before hitting the pavement. |archive-date=November 30, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161130032909/http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/public/2016/osu-attack/Ohio-State-victims-update.html}}</ref> before crashing into a brick wall.<ref name="KenndeyDeliberateRamming">{{cite news|last1=Kennedy|first1=Merrit|title=Suspect Killed After Knife And Vehicle Attack At Ohio State University|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/11/28/503589910/at-least-9-injured-following-report-of-active-shooter-at-ohio-state-university|accessdate=November 28, 2016|publisher=NPR|date=November 28, 2016|quote=Ohio State University Police Chief Craig Stone said this was a deliberate attack. 'To go over the curb and strike pedestrians, and then get out and start striking them with a knife — that was on purpose,' he told reporters during the news conference.}}</ref><ref name=Dispatch /><ref>{{cite news |title=Ten people hospitalized, suspect killed after attack on Ohio State campus |publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]'' |date=November 28, 2016 |first1=Kathy Lynn |last1=Gray |first2=Susan |last2=Svrluga |first3=Matt |last3=Zapotsky |first4=Mark |last4=Berman |accessdate=November 28, 2016 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2016/11/28/ohio-state-university-warns-of-active-shooter-on-campus/ |quote='We were waiting for the firetrucks to go. As soon as the firetrucks started to pull away, a white Honda Civic came flying into the crowd,' Chapman said. 'It probably hit three or four people. We thought it was an accident at first. Once the car had stopped, everyone was making sure the driver was okay. But he got out of the car and immediately started slashing people closest to the car with a knife.'}}</ref><ref name="ABC.Witnesses">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/witnesses-ohio-state-university-stabbings-recount-chaos/story?id=43823996|title=Witnesses to Ohio State University Stabbings Recount Chaos|publisher=ABC News|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016|first1=Emily|last1=Shapiro|first2=Michael Edison|last2=Hayden}}</ref>
As people rushed in to help the injured,<ref name="ABC.Fought">{{cite web|url=http://abc6onyourside.com/news/local/victim-grabbed-knife-as-he-tried-to-help-others|title=Army vet fought Ohio State attacker as he tried to help others after car crash|work=ABC 6 On Your Side|date=November 29, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016|first=Michele|last=Newell}}</ref> the assailant got out of the car, armed with a [[butcher knife]], "let out a war cry" according to one witness, and began attacking students.<ref name=Dispatch>{{cite web|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2016/11/28/active-shooter.html|title=Ohio State: Campus pulls together with 11 injured, assailant dead after attack|work=The Columbus Dispatch|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016}}</ref><ref name="NBC.Vowed">{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/ohio-state-victim-says-attacker-vowed-kill-her-n690306|title=Ohio State Victim Says Attacker Vowed to Kill Her|work=NBC News|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016|first=Tracy|last=Connor}}</ref> One student described a man with a knife, "chasing people around trying to attack them."<ref name="ABC.Dead"/> Another witness recounted that the attacker did not say anything as he stabbed people.<ref name="ABC.Witnesses"/> At one point, Anderson Payne, a [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] veteran who was helping people struck by the Honda Civic, grabbed the attacker's knife and ducked under his arm in order to escape, but was unable to disarm him and had his hand slashed in the process.<ref name="ABC.Fought"/> A student injured during the attack described seeing people screaming and fleeing before she encountered the assailant, who said "I'm going to kill you" and then slashed her left arm.<ref name="NBC.Vowed"/> The attacker was shot and killed by police within two minutes of the attack starting.<ref name="CNN.Attack">{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/11/28/us/ohio-state-university-active-shooter/index.html|title=Ohio State University: Attacker killed, 11 hospitalized after campus attack|first1=Emanuella|last1=Grinberg|first2=Shimon|last2=Prokupecz|first3=Holly|last3=Yan|website=CNN|date=November 28, 2016|access-date=November 28, 2016}}</ref>
Initial reports had stated that there was an [[active shooter]] incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/11/28/ohio-state-tweets-that-active-shooter-is-on-campus.html?__source=yahoo%7Cfinance%7Cheadline%7Cheadline%7Cstory&par=yahoo&doc=104132440&yptr=yahoo|title=9 people injured, 1 suspect dead after Ohio State campus attack|work=CNBC|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016|first=Berkeley Jr.|last=Lovelace|quote=The attack on campus in Columbus had initially had been described as an active shooter on the loose.}}</ref> At 9:54{{nbsp}}a.m. EST, OSU sent out an emergency notification asking students to [[shelter in place]].<ref name="10tv">{{cite web|url=http://www.10tv.com/article/reports-active-shooter-ohio-state-campus-updated|title=Attack at Ohio State campus: 11 injured, suspect killed by police|work=10-TV|date=November 28, 2016|access-date=November 28, 2016|quote=A Buckeye Alert emergency notification was sent out to the campus at 9:54 a.m. asking those on campus to shelter in place.}}</ref> At 10:19{{nbsp}}a.m. EST<!--All times are local time-->, police reported that the attacker had been killed by an officer after failing to comply with the officer's orders to put down his weapon.<ref name="CNN.Attack"/><ref name="CBSNews">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/ohio-state-university-active-shooter-on-campus/|title=At least 8 injured in Ohio State University attack; one suspect dead|date=November 28, 2016|work=[[CBS News]]|access-date=November 28, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://wtvr.com/2016/11/28/ohio-state-active-shooter/|title=Ohio State University: Attacker killed, 11 hospitalized after campus attack|publisher=WTVR|agency=CNN Wire|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016}}</ref> An academic adviser who witnessed the attack described seeing the assailant charge at police, who fired and shot him multiple times.<ref name="ABC.Witnesses"/>
The scene was declared secure and the shelter in place order was lifted on the OSU campus at around 11:30{{nbsp}}a.m. EST.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/OSU_EMFP/status/803275001755336704|title=UPDATE 1/2 : Shelter in Place lifted. Scene is now secure. ALL classes are canceled on Columbus campus for the remainder of the day.|type=[[Twitter]] post|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016}}</ref> However, subsequent Twitter posts indicated the order may have been lifted prematurely and that at least one building was still on lockdown at 12:23{{nbsp}}p.m. EST.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/TheLantern/status/803288278380126208|title=According to student at Houston House, shelter in place was "improperly" lifted. Residence hall still on lockdown.|type=[[Twitter]] post|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016}}</ref> The fluorine leak at Watts Hall was determined by authorities to have been unrelated to the attack.<ref name="Lantern.Recap">{{cite web|url=http://thelantern.com/2016/11/second-press-conference-recap-drake-kasich-ginther-and-others-speak-on-campus-incident/|title=Second press conference recap: Drake, Kasich, Ginther and others speak on campus incident|work=[[The Lantern]]|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=December 2, 2016|first1=Jacob|last1=Myers|first2=Mitch|last2=Hooper}}</ref>
=== Victims === A total of thirteen people were injured in the attack.<ref name="ColumbusDispatch.Named">{{cite web|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/public/2016/osu-attack/osu-victims.html|title=Victims in Ohio State attack named|work=The Columbus Dispatch|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016|first=Beth|last=Burger}}</ref> Eleven of them were injured directly by the attacker; most of them were struck by his vehicle, at least two suffered stab wounds, and one victim had a fractured skull. A twelfth person was shot in the foot by a stray round fired by the officer who killed the assailant, while a thirteenth person was treated for unspecified injuries.<ref name="ColumbusDispatch.Sorting"/><ref name="StarTrib.Terrorism">{{cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/attacker-stabs-people-at-ohio-state-campus/403392266/#1|title=Terrorism suspected in car-and-knife attack at Ohio State|work=Minneapolis Star-Tribune|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016|first1=Andrew|last1=Welsh-Huggins|first2=Julie Carr|last2=Smyth|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161129014536/http://www.startribune.com/attacker-stabs-people-at-ohio-state-campus/403392266/#1|archivedate=November 29, 2016|df=}}</ref><ref name="WCPO.Released">{{cite web|url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/state/state-ohio/names-of-13-ohio-state-attack-victims-released|title=Names of 13 Ohio State attack victims released|work=WCPO|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016}}</ref> The victims included nine students, one faculty member, and one university worker, while the remaining two had as-of-yet unknown backgrounds.<ref name="CBF.Identified">{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/columbus/news/2016/11/28/ohio-state-attacker-identified-as-first-year.html|title=Ohio State attacker identified as 20-year-old student|work=Columbus Business First|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016|first=Doug|last=Buchanan}}</ref><ref name="WYKC.Released">{{cite web|url=http://www.wkyc.com/news/local/ohio/osu-victim-names-released-2-from-northeastern-ohio/360109857|title=OSU victim names released; 2 from Northeastern Ohio|work=WKYC-TV|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016|first=Jessie|last=Balmert}}</ref> All of their identities were released by November 30.<ref name="ColumbusDispatch.Named"/><ref name="WCPO.Released"/><ref name="WYKC.Released"/>
=== Emergency response === [[File:OSU shooting, helicopter patrol.jpg|thumb|right|Helicopters circling over the Lane Ave Garage]] Eleven of the injured were treated at area hospitals.<ref name="WCPO.Released"/> Eight of them were sent to [[Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center|OSU Wexner Medical Center]], [[Grant Medical Center]], and [[Riverside Methodist Hospital]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2016/11/28/ohio-state-issues-shelter-place-order-after-active-shooter-report/7dfbPAUUuup8Q4grP4VttN/story.html |date=November 28, 2016 |publisher=''[[The Boston Globe]]'' |quote=The eight patients were split among OSU Wexner Medical Center, OhioHealth Grant Medical Center and OhioHealth Riverside Methodist Hospital. |title=At least 8 sent to hospital after incident at Ohio State |accessdate=November 28, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161128171515/https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2016/11/28/ohio-state-issues-shelter-place-order-after-active-shooter-report/7dfbPAUUuup8Q4grP4VttN/story.html |archive-date=November 28, 2016 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> None of the injuries were considered life-threatening.<ref name="DDN.Search">{{cite web|url=http://www.daytondailynews.com/news/ohio-state-attack-suspect-died-from-shot-head-chest/o8B7faWqVrsxoeUV45xI1J/|title=Ohio State attack: Suspect died from shot to head, chest|work=Dayton Daily News|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016|first1=Jeremy P.|last1=Kelley|first2=Laura A.|last2=Bischoff|first3=Max|last3=Filb}}</ref> Four remained hospitalized by the next day.<ref name="GlobalNews.Hails">{{cite web|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/3095152/ohio-state-university-attacker-abdul-razak-ali-artan-was-angry-about-treatment-of-muslims-official-says/|title=ISIS hails Ohio State University attacker Abdul Razak Ali Artan as ‘a soldier of the Islamic State’|publisher=Global News|agency=Associated Press|date=November 29, 2016|accessdate=November 29, 2016|first1=Julie Carr|last1=Smyth|first2=Andrew|last2=Welsh-Huggins}}</ref>
The first officer to respond to the scene of the attack was Alan Horujko, an officer with the OSU Division of Police who happened to be nearby because of a reported gas leak.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2016/11/28/officials-praise-fast-acting-officer-who-killed-ohio-state-attacker.html |publisher=''[[The Toronto Star]]'' |title=Officials praise fast-acting officer who killed Ohio State attacker |first=Andrew |last=Welsh-Huggins |quote=Officer Alan Horujko, who started on the university police force in January 2015, was responding to reports of a nearby gas leak when the car jumped a curb on campus at 9:52 a.m. |date=November 28, 2016 |accessdate=November 30, 2016}}</ref> Horujko shot and killed the assailant within a minute after the attack started.<ref name="StarTrib.Terrorism"/> The [[Columbus Division of Police]], Franklin County Sheriff's Office and the [[Ohio State Highway Patrol]] dispatched tactical teams, negotiators, a [[Police dog|K-9]] unit, and additional officers to assist campus police. In addition, a Columbus Division of Fire bomb squad was dispatched to the scene and arrived at 10:06{{nbsp}}a.m.<ref name="CBSNews"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-38136658|title=Gunman 'dead' at Ohio State University rampage|work=BBC News|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2016/11/28/ohio-state-reports-active-shooter-columbus-campus/94540050/|title=Eleven hurt, suspect killed in 'terrifying' Ohio State attack|work=USA Today|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016|first=John|last=Bacon}}</ref> The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]]'s [[Cincinnati]] office announced that its agents were assisting campus police in the investigation. Agents from the local [[Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives]] (ATF) unit were also dispatched to the scene of the attack.<ref name="NYTimes.Alert">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/28/us/active-shooter-ohio-state-university.html?_r=0|title=Suspect Is Killed in Attack at Ohio State University That Injured 11|work=The New York Times|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016|first1=Mitch|last1=Smith|first2=Richard|last2=Pérez-Peña|first3=Adam|last3=Goldman|author-link2=Richard Pérez-Peña}}</ref>
Upper Arlington and Grandview schools were locked down for a short time while police investigated the incident. The [[Ohio Department of Transportation]] temporarily closed ramp access to and from [[Ohio State Route 315|Route 315]] at Lane Avenue and Medical Center Drive.<ref name=Dispatch />
== Perpetrator == {{Infobox criminal | name = Abdul Artan | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Abdul Razak Ali Artan | religion = [[Islam]] | occupation = Student | birth_date = 1998 | death_date = {{death date and age|2016|11|28|1998|1|1}} | birth_place = [[Somalia]] | death_place = [[Columbus, Ohio]], U.S. | death_cause = Gunshot wounds to the head and chest by police | nationality = [[Somalis|Somali]] | relatives = Mother and six siblings }} '''Abdul Razak Ali Artan''' (1998 – November 28, 2016) was a Muslim [[Somalia|Somali]] refugee and [[Permanent residence (United States)|legal permanent resident]] of the United States who had been a logistics management major in the [[Max M. Fisher College of Business]] at the time of the attack.<ref name=PolID>{{cite news |url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2016/11/28/active-shooter.html |title=Ohio State attack: Police identify suspect as business student |date=November 28, 2016 |accessdate=November 28, 2016 |archive-date=November 28, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161128235741/http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2016/11/28/active-shooter.html |quote=The suspect has been identified as Abdul Razak Ali Artan, who was a Logistics Management major in the College of Business at Ohio State.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[NBC News]] |title=1 Suspect Dead, 9 in Hospital After Ohio State Car-and-Knife Attack |first1=Pete |last1=Williams |first2=Tom |last2=Winter |first3=Tracy |last3=Connor |date=November 28, 2016 |accessdate=November 28, 2016 |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/suspect-dead-after-ohio-state-university-car-knife-attack-n689076 |quote=The suspect's name was not released, but law enforcement officials told NBC News he was an 18-year-old Ohio State student, a Somali refugee who was a legal permanent resident of the United States. |archive-date=November 28, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161128191059/http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/suspect-dead-after-ohio-state-university-car-knife-attack-n689076 |deadurl=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-38136658 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=November 28, 2016 |title=Ohio attacker Abdul Ali Artan was 'Somali refugee' |quote=Abdul Razak Ali Artan, 18, rammed his car into a group of pedestrians on campus then got out and began stabbing people before police shot him dead. |archive-date=November 28, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161128204600/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-38136658 |accessdate=November 28, 2016 |deadurl=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/suspect-dead-after-ohio-state-university-car-knife-attack-n689076|title=Suspect Identified in Ohio State Attack as Abdul Razaq Ali Artan|publisher=NBC News|date=November 28, 2016|access-date=November 28, 2016|first1=Pete|last1=Williams|first2=Tom|last2=Winter|first4=Tracy|last4=Connor|first3=Andrew|last3=Blankstein|quote=Abdul Razak Ali Artan, 18, wrote on what appears to be his Facebook page that he had reached a "boiling point," made a reference to "lone wolf attacks" and cited radical cleric Anwar al-Awlaki.}}</ref> Though OSU said Artan was 18, investigators said some records conflicted and investigators believed he may have been older.<ref name="NYTimes.Soldier">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/29/us/ohio-state-university-abdul-artan-islamic-state.html|title=ISIS Calls Ohio State University Attacker a ‘Soldier’|work=The New York Times|date=November 29, 2016|accessdate=November 29, 2016|first1=Mitch|last1=Smith|first2=Rukmini|last2=Callimachi|first3=Richard|last3=Pérez-Peña|author-link3=Richard Pérez-Peña}}</ref>
Artan was the third-eldest of seven children. He alleged that he was born in a refugee camp after his family fled Somalia.<ref name="USA.Identified"/> However, a senior U.S. government official said that Artan left Somalia with the rest of his family in 2007, and that they spent seven years in a [[Somalis in Pakistan|refugee camp in Pakistan]], settling in [[Islamabad]] on a road known as "Somali Street".<ref name="NYTimes.Path"/><ref>{{cite news |title=Pakistan’s Somali Community Shocked After Attack at Ohio State University |publisher=''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' |date=November 30, 2016 |first1=Qasim |last1=Nauman |first2=Saeed |last2=Shah | url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2016/11/30/pakistans-somali-community-shocked-after-attack-at-ohio-university/ |archive-date=December 4, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161204050542/https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2016/11/30/pakistans-somali-community-shocked-after-attack-at-ohio-university/ |quote=Abdul Razak Ali Artan, who was shot and killed Monday after allegedly attacking fellow students in Ohio, lived for several years in Islamabad with his family, until he moved to the U.S. in 2014}}</ref> He moved to the U.S. on a refugee visa with his mother and six siblings in 2014.<ref name="CNN.Attack"/><ref name="CBS.Known">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/ohio-state-university-attack-whats-known-about-suspect-abdul-razak-ali-artan/|title=What's known about the OSU attack suspect Abdul Razak Ali Artan|publisher=CBS News|agency=Associated Press|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.abqjournal.com/899385/ohio-state-knife-attacker-was-nice-guy-but-unknown-to-many.html|title=Ohio State knife attacker was ‘nice guy’ but unknown to many|publisher=Albuquerque Journal|agency=Associated Press|date=December 1, 2016|accessdate=December 1, 2016|first=Andrew|last=Welsh-Huggins|quote=Artan arrived in Dallas with his mother and six siblings on June 5, 2014, according to Dave Woodyard, CEO at Catholic Charities of Dallas, which briefly offered aid to the family.}}</ref>
The Franklin County Coroner's Office, conducting a preliminary autopsy report on Artan's body, determined that he died from gunshot wounds to the head and chest.<ref name="DDN.Search"/>
=== Life in the United States === Artan and his family first settled in a temporary shelter in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]], for approximately 24 days before relocating to Columbus.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.houstonpublicmedia.org/articles/news/2016/11/29/178953/ohio-state-attacker-stayed-in-dallas-in-2014-heres-what-we-know/ |publisher=[[KERA-TV]] |date=November 29, 2016 |first=Gus |last=Contreras |title=Ohio State Attacker, Stayed In Dallas In 2014: Here’s What We Know |archive-date=December 1, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161201032922/http://www.houstonpublicmedia.org/articles/news/2016/11/29/178953/ohio-state-attacker-stayed-in-dallas-in-2014-heres-what-we-know/ |quote=Artan arrived in Dallas with his mother and six siblings, Woodyard told KERA. They arrived at D/FW International Airport from JFK International Airport, Woodyard told KXAS-TV.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/us-news/2016/11/28/ohio-state-university-attacker-spent-time-dallas-moving-us |title=Ohio State University attacker spent time in Dallas after moving to U.S. |publisher=''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' |first=Claire Z. |last=Cardona |quote=Abdul Razak Ali Artan, his mother and six siblings got help from Catholic Charities after they arrived in Dallas on June 5, 2014, KXAS-TV (NBC5) reported. |date=November 28, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161130031924/http://www.dallasnews.com/news/us-news/2016/11/28/ohio-state-university-attacker-spent-time-dallas-moving-us |archive-date=November 30, 2016 |accessdate=November 29, 2016}}</ref><ref name="NBC.Know">{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/ohio-state-attack-what-we-know-about-abdul-razak-ali-n689556|title=Ohio State Attack: What We Know About Abdul Razak Ali Artan|work=NBC News|date=November 29, 2016|accessdate=November 29, 2016|first1=Tracy|last1=Connor|first2=Pete|last2=Williams|first3=Tom|last3=Winter|first4=Jonathan|last4=Dienst}}</ref> They lived together in four units of an apartment at the Havenwood Townhomes complex in the [[West Columbus, Ohio|West Side]].<ref name="CNN.Attack"/><ref name="Dispatch.Suspect">{{cite news |publisher=''[[The Columbus Dispatch]]'' |url=http://www.cantonrep.com/news/20161128/update-attack-suspect-was-osu-student-nine-injured-on-campus |title=UPDATE: Attack suspect was OSU student; nine injured on campus |date=November 28, 2016 |accessdate=November 28, 2016 |quote=Neighbors in the Havenwood Townhome complex on the West Side said police and the sheriff's office bomb squad have been searching an apartment there since shortly before 11 am., not long after the situation on campus occurred.}}</ref> He was described by neighbors as a consistently polite man who always "attended daily prayer services at a mosque" in Columbus.<ref name="AP.Suspected">{{cite news|first1=Andrew|last1=Welsh-Huggins|first2=Julie Carr|last2=Smyth|title=Terrorism suspected in car-and-knife attack at Ohio State|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/dbb10667234a4eaa9548643e0977be5e/ohio-state-tweets-active-shooter-campus|accessdate=November 28, 2016|work=Associated Press|date=November 28, 2016}}</ref> Friends in Ohio and Pakistan described him as a "studious, devout young man who 'loved America'" and "did not have any extremist tendencies."<ref name="NBC.Bought">{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/ohio-state-attacker-may-have-been-inspired-isis-al-awlaki-n690236|title=Ohio State Attacker Abdul Razak Ali Artan Bought Knife in Washington|work=NBC News|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016|first1=Pete|last1=Williams|first2=Jonathan|last2=Dienst|first3=Tracy|last3=Connor}}</ref><ref name="NYTimes.Path">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/01/us/from-somalia-to-us-ohio-state-attackers-path-to-violence.html|title=From Somalia to U.S.: Ohio State Attacker’s Path to Violence|work=The New York Times|date=December 1, 2016|accessdate=December 1, 2016|first1=Mitch|last1=Smith|first2=Adam|last2=Goldman}}</ref> He and his family did not appear to be familiar figures at local mosques and in Somali community groups, according to leaders there.<ref name="NYTimes.Soldier"/> According to a police report, before settling into Havenwood Townhomes, Artan and his family contacted police in 2014 after an animal heart was left on the hood of a relative's car.<ref name="ColumbusDispatch.Sorting"/>
Artan previously attended [[Columbus State Community College]] from the fall of 2014 to the summer of 2016, and graduated [[cum laude]] with an [[Associate of Arts]] degree,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cscc.edu/services/graduation/pdf2/GradProgram.May2016.pdf |page=18 |title=Commencement Ceremonies |date=May 13, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161129001202/http://www.cscc.edu/services/graduation/pdf2/GradProgram.May2016.pdf |archive-date=November 29, 2016 |publisher=[[Columbus State Community College]] |accessdate=November 28, 2016}}</ref> after which he transferred to OSU.<ref name="GrayAttacker">{{cite news|last1=Gray|first1=Kathy|title=Ohio State student identified as campus attacker, nearly a dozen hospitalized|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2016/11/28/ohio-state-university-warns-of-active-shooter-on-campus/|accessdate=November 28, 2016|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=November 28, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/osu-attack-suspect-identified-abdul-razak-ali-artan/story?id=43827435|title=Officials Investigating Anti-US Facebook Rant Believed Linked to OSU Attacker|publisher=ABC News|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016|first1=Brian|last1=Ross|first2=Mike|last2=Levine|first3=Josh|last3=Margolin|first4=Aaron|last4=Katersky}}</ref><ref name="Time.Know">{{cite web|url=http://time.com/4584259/ohio-state-university-attack-artan/|title=What to Know About Ohio State University Attacker Abdul Razak Ali Artan|work=Time|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016|first=Mahita|last=Gajanan}}</ref> He had no disciplinary record at Columbus State,<ref name="USA.Identified">{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2016/11/28/somali-immigrant-identified-attacker-ohio-state/94563226/|title=Ohio State student identified as attacker|work=USA Today|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016|first=Aamer|last=Madhani}}</ref> and was described as "very normal" and talking about Islam frequently by his classmates there.<ref name="NYTimes.Path"/> At the time of the attack, he was enrolled in fourteen-and-a-half credit hours for the semester.<ref name="NYTimes.Path"/> Artan had worked at a [[Home Depot]] in Columbus for less than a year.<ref>{{cite news |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=November 28, 2016 |quote=That employee who asked not to be named, said he had seen Artan as recently as last week. Store management declined to comment. A Home Depot spokesman confirmed that Artan was currently employed by the company and had worked there for less than a year. |first=Darran |last=Simon |accessdate=November 28, 2016 |title=Ohio State attacker said he was 'scared' to pray in public |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161129052657/http://www.cnn.com/2016/11/28/us/ohio-state-attacker-abdul-razak-ali-artan/ |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/11/28/us/ohio-state-attacker-abdul-razak-ali-artan/ |archive-date=November 29, 2016}}</ref>
In August, on his first day at OSU, Artan was interviewed by ''[[The Lantern]]'', the school newspaper. In the interview, he said that he was having trouble finding a place to pray in comparison to his old school at Columbus State, which provided private prayer rooms. However, he was apparently unaware of a prayer space provided in the OSU student union. Artan added that he was scared about other people's opinions of him because of what he perceived to be negative portrayal of Muslims in the media, and criticized the then Presidential candidate [[Donald Trump]] for not being "educated on Islam".<ref name="CBS.Known"/><ref name="NYTimes.Path"/><ref name="Time.Know"/><ref>{{cite news |title=Humans of Ohio State |first=Kevin |last=Stankiewicz |publisher=''[[The Lantern]]'' |via=[[issuu]] |date=October 18, 2016 |url=https://issuu.com/thelantern/docs/082516/5 |accessdate=November 28, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whio.com/news/local/ohio-state-attack-who-the-suspect/xTzV8374LqMo6wvsdOZ2LL/|title=OHIO STATE ATTACK: Who is the suspect?|publisher=WHIO|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016}}</ref> In the interview, Artan expressed fear about Donald Trump’s rhetoric toward Muslims, and what it might mean for immigrants and refugees.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2016/11/30/i-interviewed-the-ohio-state-attacker-on-the-first-day-of-school-it-felt-important-now-its-chilling/|title= I interviewed the Ohio State attacker on the first day of school. It felt important. Now it’s chilling.|first=Kevin|last=Stankiewicz|date=November 30, 2016}}</ref>
== Investigation == The FBI's [[Joint Terrorism Task Force]] and the ATF became involved in the investigation.<ref name="NYTimes.Alert"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/public/2016/osu-attack/isis-claims-responsibility-for-ohio-state-attack.html|title=ISIS claims credit for inspiring attack at Ohio State that injured 11|work=The Columbus Dispatch|date=November 29, 2016|accessdate=November 29, 2016|first1=Earl|last1=Rinehart|first2=Beth|last2=Burger|quote=The case is being investigated as a potential terrorist act by the FBI's Joint Terrorism Task Force, which includes Columbus police, Columbus police spokesman Rich Weiner said.}}</ref> The investigation is ongoing; police have not ruled out terrorism as a motive as of November 28.<ref name="GrayAttacker"/>
Per university policy, Alan Horujko, the campus officer who shot and killed Artan, was placed on administrative leave. Columbus police began investigating the officer-involved shooting.<ref name="WYKC.Released"/>
Though two people were taken into custody in the immediate aftermath of the attack,<ref name="DDN.Search"/> Artan was ultimately believed by police to have acted alone.<ref name="CBF.Identified"/> His apartment was searched by the FBI and a Franklin County Sheriff's Office bomb squad.<ref name="Dispatch.Suspect"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2016/11/fbi_searching_house_of_suspect.html |title=FBI searches house of suspect in Ohio State campus attack |publisher=[[Cleveland.com]] |date=November 28, 2016 |accessdate=November 28, 2016 |first=Adam |last=Ferrise |quote=Dozens of FBI agents showed up at the apartment of Abdul Razak Ali Artan about 7 p.m. Monday. Agents carried briefcases, large equipment and evidence boxes into the Havenwood Townhome Community complex on Nationwide Boulevard while Franklin County deputies blocked off the street and stood guard outside the building.}}</ref>
On November 30, the FBI appealed to the public for assistance in filling in an unaccounted time gap between Artan's purchase of a knife on the morning of the attack and the attack itself.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/11/30/us/ohio-state-university-attack/|title=Ohio State University attack investigation: FBI asks public for help|work=CNN|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=December 2, 2016|first=Catherine E.|last=Shoichet}}</ref>
=== Terrorism classification === The FBI began a search into Artan's digital history to see if he had contact with suspected terrorists or had access to terrorist propaganda.<ref name="FOX.Declaration">{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2016/11/28/fbi-investigates-possible-facebook-declaration-by-osu-attack-suspect.html|title=FBI investigates possible Facebook 'declaration' by OSU attack suspect|publisher=Fox News|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016|quote=Law enforcement sources told Fox News that the FBI is combing through Artan’s digital history and devices to see if he had contact with any suspected terrorists and for any traces of terrorist propaganda.}}</ref> Artan had not been known to the FBI as a potential threat prior to the attack.<ref name="GlobalNews.Hails"/><ref name="Yahoo.Inspired">{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/ohio-state-attacker-may-inspired-overseas-militants-fbi-185743642.html|title=Ohio State attacker may have been inspired by overseas militants: FBI|publisher=Yahoo! News|agency=Reuters|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016|first=Alex|last=Dobuzinskis}}</ref>
In the hours after the attack, the FBI focused on a [[Facebook]] post that, according to CNN, was written by Artan minutes before the attack.<ref name="MettlerFacebookPost">{{cite news|last1=Mettler|first1=Kate|title=Ohio State attacker complained bitterly in Facebook post of treatment of Muslims 'everywhere,' reports say|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2016/11/29/ohio-state-attacker-in-facebook-post-complained-bitterly-of-treatment-of-muslims-everywhere-reports-say/|accessdate=November 29, 2016|agency=CNN|publisher=The Washington Post|date=November 29, 2016}}</ref> According [[CBS News]], the Facebook post suggests "he was disturbed by how Muslims were being treated everywhere"<ref>{{cite news|title=OSU suspect reportedly posted angry Facebook message before attack|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/ohio-state-university-osu-attack-facebook-post-muslim-suspect-abdul-razak-ali-artan/|date=November 29, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016|work=CBS News|quote=...Facebook suggesting that he was disturbed by how Muslims were being treated, reports CBS News correspondent Jeff Pegues. Artan reportedly posted: 'I am sick and tired of seeing my fellow Muslim brothers and sisters being killed and tortured EVERYWHERE.'}}</ref> and appears to be concerned with the violence and [[persecution of Muslims in Myanmar]].<ref>{{cite web |quote=From his Facebook post, it appears Artan harbored particular anger over reported violence in Burma (a country also known as Myanmar), where U.N. officials have sounded the alarm in recent days over what one official characterized to BBC News as the 'ethnic cleansing of the Muslim minority,' in the country. |url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/state/state-ohio/abdul-razak-ali-artan-ohio-state-attackers-anti-america-facebook-rant-eyed-as-motive-campus-attack|title=Ohio State attacker's anti-America Facebook rant eyed as motive in campus attack|work=WCPO|date=November 29, 2016|accessdate=November 29, 2016}}</ref> In that same post, Artan also "criticized the United States for interfering in other countries."<ref>{{cite news|title=Neighbor, Facebook post show 2 sides of Ohio State attacker|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/public/2016/Ohio-State-attacker.html|date=November 29, 2016|first=Earl|last=Rinehart|accessdate=November 30, 2016|work=he Columbus Dispatch|quote=In it, he criticized the United States for interfering in other countries and said that, 'If you want us Muslims to stop carrying lone wolf attacks, then make peace.'}}</ref> A senior FBI official said that investigators are currently working to verify the authenticity of the posts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/ohio-state-attacker-may-have-been-inspired-by-isis-1480536149?mod=e2fb|title=Ohio State Attacker May Have Been Inspired by ISIS|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016|first=Melissa|last=Korn|quote=[Angela] Byers said officials are determining the authenticity of Facebook posts Mr. Artan may have made regarding his anger over perceived mistreatment of Muslims, and they are analyzing electronic devices found in a search of his home.}}</ref> The full statement has been [[#External links|released by police and published]].
On the day after the attack, two law enforcement sources confirmed investigators' beliefs that Artan was inspired by terrorist propaganda from ISIL and al-Awlaki, citing Artan's Facebook post and the method used to carry out the attack. The sources added that Artan has currently not been found to have any communication with terror groups, and that the attack appears to be an act of a [[lone wolf (terrorism)|lone wolf]].<ref name="CNN.Inspired"/> These sources were confirmed by an FBI official on November 30.<ref name="Yahoo.Inspired"/> Other law enforcement officials said that Artan may have been motivated by exposure to a "mix of radical messages" from both ISIL and [[Al-Qaeda]], much like the perpetrators of [[2015 San Bernardino attack|the San Bernardino attack]] in December 2015, and the September 2016 [[2016 New York and New Jersey bombings|bombings and bombing attempts in New York and New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/ohio-state-university-attack-abdul-razak-ali-arta-may-have-come-out-of-the-blue/|title=Ohio State attacker may have been inspired by radical messages|work=CBS News|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016}}</ref> On November 30, a senior official of the FBI's Cincinnati division claimed it was "too early to speculate on the extent of" Artan's involvement with ISIL.<ref name="ColumbusDispatch.Sorting"/>
Despite ISIL's claim of responsibility for the attack (see [[#Reactions|below]]), it was reported that no evidence has emerged to suggest the terrorist organization's foreknowledge of the event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/details-emerge-ohio-state-community-make-sense-attack/story?id=43864565|title=Details Emerge as Ohio State Community Tries to Make Sense of Attack|work=ABC News|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016|first1=Brian|last1=Ross|first2=Mike|last2=Levine|quote=While ISIS has repeatedly called on its followers to conduct attacks in the U.S., no evidence has emerged publicly to suggest ISIS had foreknowledge of the OSU plot.}}</ref>
On June 1, 2017, investigators announced that Artan left a torn-up note to his parents in which he pledged his allegiance to ISIL, asked his family to stop being [[Moderate Muslim|moderate]], and said he was upset by the persecution of Muslims in Myanmar.<ref>{{cite news|first1=Andrew|last1=Welsh-Huggins|title=APNewsBreak: Ohio State attacker faulted ‘moderate’ Muslims|url=https://apnews.com/d36b9b5261be46678eb6b7dc910ee681/APNewsBreak:-Ohio-State-attacker-faulted-'moderate'-Muslims|accessdate=June 3, 2017|work=The Associated Press|date=June 1, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first1=Steve|last1=Levine|title=OSU knife attacker left handwritten, ripped up note behind in home|url=http://abc6onyourside.com/news/local/osu-knife-attacker-left-ripped-up-note-behind-in-his-home|accessdate=June 3, 2017|work=ABC News 6 - WSYX/WTTE|date=June 1, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first1=Tara|last1=Morgan|title=Case file reveals new information about Ohio State campus attack|url=http://abc6onyourside.com/news/local/osu-attack-case-file-reveals-new-information-about-that-day-last-november|accessdate=June 3, 2017|work=ABC 6|date=June 2, 2017}}</ref>
== Reactions ==
=== University reaction === [[File:2016 Ohio State University attack dedication.jpg|thumb|200px|Poinsettias and a sign left outside of Watts Hall in dedication of the attack.]]
Soon after the attack, OSU tweeted that all classes would be canceled for the rest of November 28.<ref name="WWL.Timeline"/> In a press conference held sometime after, OSU President [[Michael V. Drake]] said that he met with Alan Horujko and thanked him for "following his training and being able to neutralize the circumstance within roughly one minute".<ref name="Lantern.Recap"/> He also credited the school's [[active shooter]] training and campus alert system for maintaining order while police secured the scene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cltv.com/2016/11/29/ohio-state-suspect-abdul-razak-ali-artan-posted-facebook-rant-before-attack/|title=Ohio State suspect Abdul Razak Ali Artan posted Facebook rant before attack|work=Chicagoland Television|date=November 29, 2016|accessdate=December 2, 2016|quote=Ohio State President Dr. Michael V. Drake and others credited the school's active shooter training and the campus alert system for helping the community maintain order while the scene was secured.}}</ref> When asked if the attack had anything to do with terrorism or Ohio's Somali-American community, Drake cautioned against "jumping to conclusions", citing a lack of evidence at the time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.localnews8.com/news/national-world/active-shooter-reported-on-ohio-state-university-campus-1/189300902|title=Ohio State University: Attacker killed, 11 hospitalized after campus attack|publisher=KIDK|agency=NBC News|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=December 2, 2016|first=Emanuella|last=Grinberg|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161202172209/http://www.localnews8.com/news/national-world/active-shooter-reported-on-ohio-state-university-campus-1/189300902|archivedate=December 2, 2016|df=}}</ref>
At around 10:00{{nbsp}}p.m. on November 28, OSU students and employees gathered in front of a church located near the scene of the attack, to pray for the injured.<ref name="WWL.Timeline"/> On November 30, two days after the attack, more than 500 students, employees, and community members attended the "#BuckeyeStrong" event at [[St. John Arena]]. Drake spoke at the event, praising the heroic acts of the school community in the immediate aftermath of the attack, as well as the work of the first responders.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.osu.edu/features/2016/moving-forward-staying-buckeye-strong.html|title=Moving forward. Staying Buckeye Strong.|work=Ohio State University|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=December 2, 2016}}</ref>
On December 1, Stephanie Clemons Thompson, assistant director of student life at OSU, made a [[Facebook]] post calling for compassion to be directed at Artan and hashtagging #BuckeyeStrong #BlackLivesMatter #SayHisName. The post received condemnation on social media for defending a person who attempted to kill others, for implying that Artan's death was wrong, and for comparing a terrorist who targeted his fellow students with victims of police brutality. A [[Change.org]] petition calling for Thompson's termination from OSU received over 1,200 signatures. An OSU spokesman said that the post "clearly is not an official statement of the university and represents her own personal viewpoint." Some people have defended Thompson for writing the post.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2016/12/01/a-school-official-called-for-compassion-for-the-ohio-state-attacker-people-are-demanding-she-be-fired/|title=A school official called for compassion for the Ohio State attacker. People are demanding she be fired.|work=The Washington Post|date=December 1, 2016|accessdate=December 2, 2016|first=Susan|last=Svrluga}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2016/12/ohio_state_administrator_faces.html|title=Ohio State University administrator faces calls for dismissal after seeking compassion for student who attacked|work=Cleveland.com|date=December 2, 2016|accessdate=December 2, 2016|first=Karen|last=Farkas}}</ref>
=== Politicians === Governor [[John Kasich]] [[tweeted]] his condolences to the school community and urged people to "listen to first responders".<ref name="NYTimes.Alert"/> He later praised the "professional, coordinated response" of first responders in another official statement.<ref name="WABC.Campus">{{cite web|url=http://abc7ny.com/news/ohio-state-student-drives-into-crowd-stabs-people-on-campus/1628709/|title=Ohio State Student Drives Into Crowd, Stabs People on Campus|publisher=WABC-TV|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016}}</ref> Mayor [[Andrew Ginther]] said that he met with several of the injured, and also declared the city's solidarity with OSU and praised the actions of Alan Horujko and other law enforcement officers.<ref name="DDN.Search"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nbc4i.com/2016/11/28/active-shooter-reported-at-osu-campus/|title=Officer who stopped Ohio State stabbing attack identified, 11 people hospitalized|publisher=NBC4I|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016|quote='I have personally met with several of the victims this afternoon, and I am pleased to report that their spirits are good and they are receiving the best of care. The City stands with The Ohio State University in supporting all those who were impacted by today’s traumatic events, and will work with Ohio State to help the university community heal physically and emotionally in the days and weeks to come.'}}</ref> President [[Barack Obama]] was briefed on the attack.<ref name="WABC.Campus"/>
Vice President-elect [[Mike Pence]] called the attack "tragic" and expressed his condolences.<ref name="AP.Suspected"/> In a [[Facebook]] post, [[President-elect of the United States|President-elect]] [[Donald Trump]] thanked the [[first responder]]s present at the scene of the attack for "react[ing] immediately and eliminat[ing] the threat on campus."<ref>{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Allan|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/donald-trump-responds-ohio-state-2016-11|title=Trump responds to Ohio State attack, thanks first responders|work=[[Business Insider]]|date=November 28, 2016|accessdate=November 28, 2016|quote=President-elect Donald Trump on Monday responded to an attack at Ohio State University in a Facebook post, thanking first responders for quickly eliminating 'the threat on campus.'}}</ref> He later tweeted that Artan "should not have been in our country."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/donald-trump-tweets-about-ohio-state-university-stabbing-attack/|title=Donald Trump tweets about Ohio State University stabbing attack|work=CBS News|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016|quote=President-elect Donald Trump weighed in on the Ohio State University attack in a tweet early Wednesday morning, claiming that the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) was 'taking credit' for the attack. The tweet also claimed that the suspect, a Somali refugee, 'should not have been in our country.'}}</ref>
=== Muslim and Somali-American reaction === The attack was condemned by several leaders of Muslim organizations and mosques in the Columbus and Greater Detroit area.<ref name="AP.Suspected"/> Imad Hamad, Executive Director of the American Human Rights Council, released a statement denouncing the assault and cautioned against scapegoating the wider Muslim community.<ref>{{cite web|title=AHRC condemns heinous Ohio State University attack|url=http://thearabdailynews.com/2016/11/30/ahrc-condemns-heinous-ohio-state-university-attack/|publisher=Arab News Daily|accessdate=21 December 2016}}</ref> Omar Hassan, president of the Somali Community Association of Ohio, likewise expressed shock at the attack, and asserted that the community put a great amount of effort into preventing radicalization. The leader of the mosque that Artan frequented also indicated that while he was not familiar with him, the mosque had numerous programs dedicated to helping youth and preventing self-radicalization.<ref name="WWL.Timeline">{{cite web|url=http://www.wwltv.com/news/local/updates-classes-to-resume-at-ohio-state-on-tuesday/356923983|title=Timeline of Ohio State University attacks|work=WWL-TV|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016}}</ref>
=== After-effects === Colleges across the U.S. began revisiting their emergency response plans as a result of the attack.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/ohio-state-attack-prompts-colleges-to-review-emergency-response-plans-1480605230|title=Ohio State Attack Prompts Colleges to Review Emergency-Response Plans|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=December 1, 2016|accessdate=December 1, 2016|first1=Melissa|last1=Korn|first2=Kris|last2=Maher|first3=Douglas|last3=Belkin|quote=Colleges nationwide are revisiting their emergency-response plans in the wake of the attack on the Ohio State University campus Monday that left 11 injured and the attacker dead.}}</ref>
The attack prompted calls to allow firearms on campuses in Ohio. [[Ohio House of Representatives|State Representative]] [[Ron Maag]] made a proposal for the expansion of "[[concealed carry]] locations". The proposal downgraded the felony charge of illegally bringing a gun on campus to a misdemeanor, and gave universities the option to allow concealed firearms on their campuses. The proposal was met with a mixed response, with proponents saying that students would feel safer with access to concealed firearms, and opponents arguing that the expansion of concealed carry locations is unnecessary and could even complicate law enforcement response.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/politics/2016/11/30/after-osu-attack-should-ohio-allow-concealed-carry-campus/94640798/|title=After OSU attack, should Ohio allow concealed carry on campus?|work=Cincinnati.com|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016|first=Jessie|last=Balmert}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/state/state-ohio/in-wake-of-osu-attack-should-guns-be-allowed-on-university-campuses-|title=In wake of OSU attack, should guns be allowed on university campuses?|work=WCPO|date=November 29, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016|first=Liam|last=Niemeyer|quote=In the aftermath of an attack on Ohio State University’s campus, a bill could be passed in the Ohio Senate that would reduce the penalty from a felony to a misdemeanor for having a gun on a university campus. All university-mandated rules prohibiting guns on campus would continue to remain in effect if the bill becomes law, but universities would now have the choice as to whether to keep those mandated rules.}}</ref>
Following the OSU attack and [[Orlando nightclub shooting|a mass shooting at a gay nightclub]] in [[Orlando, Florida]], in which at least one victim bled to death, a new federal initiative was launched. It was designed to train people working at schools and other public places on how to treat injuries before paramedics arrive at the scene. Doctors have emphasized the importance for school faculty members to stay calm and assess injuries, but also discouraged the use of more invasive emergency procedures such as removing a bullet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/ohio-state-university-attack-need-training-ordinary-people-save-lives/|title=Ohio State University attack highlights need for training ordinary people to save lives|publisher=CBS News|agency=Associated Press|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016}}</ref>
=== ISIL claim of responsibility === [[Amaq News Agency]], a purported ISIL mouthpiece, released a statement calling Artan a "soldier of the Islamic State" who "carried out the operation in response to calls to target citizens of international coalition countries."<ref name="GlobalNews.Hails"/><ref name="NBC.Know"/><ref name="DesantisISIS">{{cite news|last1=Desantis|first1=Candace Goforth|last2=Brown|first2=Stephen Rex|title=ISIS takes responsibility for Ohio State attack, proclaims Abdul Artan a 'soldier'|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/ohio-state-attacker-ranted-muslim-sleeper-cell-article-1.2891401|accessdate=November 29, 2016|publisher=The New York Daily News|date=November 29, 2016|quote=The Somali-born Ohio State student who rammed his car into a crowd before attacking them with a butcher knife was an ISIS 'soldier,' the terrorist group proclaimed Tuesday.}}</ref><ref name="HellmanISIS">{{cite news|last1=Hellman|first1=Jesse|title=ISIS claims responsibility for Ohio State attack|url=http://thehill.com/policy/national-security/307907-isis-claims-responsibility-for-ohio-state-university-attack|accessdate=November 29, 2016|quote=The terror group's Amaq News Agency on Tuesday claimed the attack, carried out by an 18-year-old Ohio State student, was perpetrated by a 'soldier of the Islamic State.'|publisher=The Hill|date=November 29, 2016}}</ref>
