{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Orphan|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox event | title = Shooting of Ong Teik Kwong | image = | caption = | date = {{start date|df=yes|2016|12|01}} | time = About 19:30 [[Time in Malaysia|MYT]] (11:30 UTC) | place = Tun Dr Lim Chong Eu Expressway, [[Penang]], [[Malaysia]] | coordinates = | cause = [[Mental illness]]{{cite web|url=http://m.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/penang-shooting-suspect-mentally-ill-with-military-background-cops-say|title=Penang shooting suspect ‘mentally ill’ with military background, cops say|publisher=The Malay Mail|date=2 December 2016|accessdate=12 June 2017}} | reported deaths = 3 deaths;
Ong Teik Kwong, Choi Hon Ming, M. Senthil | reported injuries = 4 injured;
Muhamad Amirul Amin Amir, Nurul Huda Abdul Aziz, Arivarni Krishnann, Lee Hong Boon | arrests = Ong's personal bodyguard, Ja'afar Halid and Lim Boon Leng }} The '''shooting of [[Datuk#Malaysia|Datuk]] Ong Teik Kwong''' occurred on 1 December 2016, in Tun Dr Lim Chong Eu Expressway, [[Penang]], [[Malaysia]]. Ong, a 32-years-old [[businessman]] was on the way to Penang when his bodyguard, Ja'afar Halid had pulled out his gun and started shooting at him and the passenger. Ja'afar Halid accidentally shot at more than seven people in the scene, resulting in Ong's and two passers-by's death. The incident also left four injured. == Background == Datuk Ong Teik Kwong was a 32-years-old business man and was the chairman of Persatuan Kebajikan Amal CK One.{{cite web|title=Bodyguard shoots dead his new boss|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/12/03/bodyguard-shoots-dead-his-new-boss-man-hired-for-job-just-a-day-before/|accessdate=6 December 2016}} Police have identified Ong as the deputy leader of the notorious Gang 24 in Penang.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2017/03/22/penang-shooting-accused-bodyguard-says-he-cant-afford-a-lawyer/|title=Penang shooting: Accused bodyguard says he can't afford a lawyer - Nation {{!}} The Star Online|website=www.thestar.com.my|access-date=22 March 2017}} The Ong's bodyguard, Ja'afar Halid who was believed be mentally unstable, was on the first day at work when the shooting happens.{{cite web|title=Slain Datuk was heading home|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/12/04/slain-datuk-was-heading-home-we-were-planning-to-have-dinner-together-says-wife/|accessdate=6 December 2016}} == Shooting == At about 19:30 MYT (11:30 UTC), on the route to Penang, Ong and his business partner, Lim Boon Leng were seated on the front while Ja'afar Halid was seated behind. Halid shot Ong from behind and hit him in the head after having an argument with Ong.{{cite web|title=A heated argument, and bodyguard opens fire|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/12/03/a-heated-argument-and-bodyguard-opens-fire/|accessdate=7 December 2016}} The car Ong was driving crashed into several vehicles in front of his. Lim panicked as the bodyguard targeted him and ran out of the car while Halid chasing him, attempted to shoot Lim for multiple times. All the 17 shots{{cite web|title=Penang shooting: Bodyguard argued with his boss before firing shots|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/videos/2016/12/03/penang-shooting-bodyguard-argued-with-his-boss-before-firing-shots/|accessdate=7 December 2016}} missed which resulted in two other deaths and four people injured. Later, Lim got a ride from a female driver who dropped him at petrol kiosk. Lim then called his friends to send him to the Penang hospital.{{cite web|title=Bodyguard upset by questioning|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/12/05/bodyguard-upset-by-questioning-he-was-queried-for-taking-out-firearm-in-public/|accessdate=6 December 2016}} === Casualties === A 28-years-old [[Radio Televisyen Malaysia|RTM]] cameraman, Muhamad Amirul Amin Amir was shot in the chest was sent to the hospital immediately as well as others who were 38-years-old [[Tenaga Nasional|TNB]] assistant manager, Nurul Huda Abdul Aziz, 33-years-old doctor, Arivarni Krishnann, and a 56-years-old factory worker, Lee Hong Boon.{{cite web|title=Datuk's bodyguard held over Penang expressway shooting|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/12/01/datuks-bodyguard-held-over-penang-expressway-shooting/|accessdate=7 December 2016}} Later after the incident, the bystanders who were dead on scene after being shot were identified as Choi Hon Ming, a Chinese 32-year-old full-time-clown, and M. Senthil, an Indian 38-years-old florist.{{cite web|title=15 minutes later I heard the terrible news, says wife of slain Penang businessman|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/12/03/man-on-way-back-for-dinner-with-wife-when-he-was-shot-dead-penang/|accessdate=6 December 2016}} == Aftermath == === Arrests and investigation === Ja'afar Halid was arrested on the scene and Lim was later detained. The Malaysia police had carried out investigation under [[Penal Code (Malaysia)#Chapter XVI: Offences Affecting the Human Body|Section 302]] of the [[Penal Code (Malaysia)|Malaysia Penal Code]] for murder.{{cite web|title=Slain Datuk was EO detainee|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/12/07/slain-datuk-was-eo-detainee-ong-arrested-several-times-by-cops-but-not-charged-with-any-crime/|accessdate=7 December 2016}} Halid and Lim had been remanded a total of seven days to facilitate investigation. Police had closed some part of Dr Lim Chong Eu Expressway to enable the forensics team to carry out investigation on 7 December 2016 between 10:30 until 17:00.{{cite web|title=Part of expressway to be closed for probe into Penang shooting|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/12/05/part-of-expressway-to-be-closed-for-probe-into-penang-shooting/|accessdate=7 December 2016}}{{cite web|title=Police: Tun Dr Lim Chong Eu Expressway, Penang Bridge to close on Dec 7 to facilitate murder probe|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/police-tun-dr-lim-chong-eu-expressway-penang-bridge-to-close-on-dec-7-to-fa|accessdate=8 December 2016|date=5 December 2016}} === Charges === Halid faced three charged for three murders, five attempted murders and causing hurt with a weapon. Under Section 302 of Malaysia Penal Code which is murdering, Halid will be punished with death upon conviction. Others are Section 307 which is attempt to murder and Section 324 which is voluntarily causing hurt by a weapon.{{cite web|title=Penang shooting: Bodyguard slapped with charges, faces death penalty|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2016/12/14/penang-shooting-bodyguard-slapped-with-charges-faces-death-penalty/|accessdate=14 December 2016}} The judge of the [[Sessions Court]], Roslan Hamid advised Halid to engage a [[counsel]] through the National Legal Aid Foundation because Halid cannot afford one. He denied trying to kill the bystanders and injuring Lim Boon Leng.{{cite web|title=Penang shooting: Accused bodyguard says he can't afford a lawyer|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2017/03/22/penang-shooting-accused-bodyguard-says-he-cant-afford-a-lawyer/|accessdate=6 May 2017}} == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:2016 in Malaysia]] [[Category:Crime in Malaysia]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Malaysia]]

[[File:Tatari Romania 2002.png|thumb|Distribution of Tatars in Romania (2002 census)]] '''Tatars''' ({{lang-ro|Tătari}}), a [[Turkic languages|Turkic]]-speaking ethnic group, have been present on the territory of today's [[Romania]] since the 13th century. According to the 2011 census, 20,282 people declared their nationality as Tatar, most of them being [[Crimean Tatars]] living in [[Constanţa County]]. They are the main factor of [[Islam in Romania]].
==History== {{further|Tatars|Tartary}} ===Middle Ages=== The roots of the Crimean Tatar community in Romania began{{how|date=September 2016}} with the [[Cumans|Cuman]] migration in the 10th century. Even before the Cumans arrived, other Turkic people like the [[Huns]] and the [[Bulgars]] settled in this region. The Tatars first reached the mouths of the [[Danube]] in the mid-13th century at the height of the power of the [[Golden Horde]]. In 1241, under the leadership of Kadan, the Tatars crossed the Danube, conquering and devastating{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} the region. The region was probably not under the direct rule of the Horde, but rather, a vassal of the [[Bakhchisaray]] Khan.<ref name="Stan44">Stănciugel et al., p.44-46</ref> It is known from Arab sources that at the end of the 13th century and the beginning of the 14th century that descendants of the [[Nogai Horde]] settled in [[Isaccea]]. Another Arab scholar, [[Ibn Battuta]], who passed through the region in 1330–31, talks about ''Baba Saltuk'' ([[Babadag]]) as the southernmost town of the Tatars.<ref name="Stan44"/>
The Golden Horde began to lose its influence after the wars of 1352-1359 and at the time, a Tatar warlord [[Demetrius, Prince of the Tatars|Demetrius]] is noted defending the cities of the Mouths of the Danube. In the 14th and 15th centuries the [[Ottoman Empire]] colonized [[Dobruja]] with [[Nogais]] from [[Budjak|Bucak]]. Between 1593 and 1595 Tatars from Nogai and [[Budjak|Bucak]] were also settled to Dobruja. (Frederick de Jong)
===Early modern period=== Toward the end of the 16th century, about 30,000 Nogai Tatars from the [[Budjak]] were brought to [[Dobruja]].<ref name="Stan147">Stănciugel et al., p.147</ref>
After the [[Russo-Turkish War, 1768-1774|Russian annexation of Crimea]] in 1783 [[Crimean Tatars]] began emigrating to the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] coastal provinces of [[Dobruja]] (today divided between [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]]). Once in Dobruja most settled in the areas surrounding [[Medgidia|Mecidiye]], [[Babadag]], [[Constanţa|Köstence]], [[Tulcea|Tulça]], [[Silistra|Silistre]], [[Beștepe, Tulcea|Beştepe]], or [[Varna]] and went on to create villages named in honor of their abandoned homeland such as Şirin, Yayla, Akmecit, Yalta, Kefe or Beybucak.{{when|date=September 2016}}
===Late modern period=== From 1783 to 1853 tens of thousands of Crimean Tatars and [[Nogais]] emigrated to the [[Rousse|Rusçuk]] region which subsequently became known as "Little Tartary". Following the Russian conquest of 1812, Nogais from Bucak also immigrated to Dobruja. Tatars who settled in Dobruja before the great exodus of 1860 were known as ''Kabail''. They formed the Kabail Tatar squadron in the ''[[Nizam-ı Cedid]]'' (New Order) army of sultan [[Selim III]]. They played a key role in [[Mahmud II]]'s struggle with [[Mehmet Ali Pasha]] of Egypt, suppressed rebellions in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Kurdistan]], and the Arab provinces and served with the Ottomans during the [[Crimean War]].
Tatars together with Albanians served as [[Bashi-bazouk|gendarmes]], who were held in high esteem by the Ottomans and received special tax privileges. The Ottoman's additionally accorded a certain degree of autonomy for the Tatars who were allowed governance by their own [[kaymakam]], Khan Mirza. The [[Giray dynasty]] (1427 - 1878) multiplied in Dobruja and maintained their respected position. A Dobrujan Tatar, [[Kara Hussein]], was responsible for the destruction of the [[Janissary]] corps on orders from Sultan Mahmut II.
From 1877-1878 it is estimated that between 80,000 and 100,000 Crimean Tatars emigrated from Dobruja to [[Anatolia]], which continued in smaller numbers until World War I. The reasons for the emigration were several: In 1883 the Romanian government enacted laws requiring compulsory military service for all Romanian subjects including Tatars who were concerned that serving a Christian army was not in accord with their Muslim identity. Other reasons included the 1899 famine in Dobruja, a series of laws from 1880 to 1885 regarding confiscation of Tatar and Turkish land, and the [[Balkan Wars]] (1912–13) which devastated the region.
==Early 20th century to WWII== [[Image:Dobethn1903.png|300px|thumb|Nationalities in Northern Dobruja at the beginning of the 20th century, with Tatars in yellow]]
A unique Crimean Tatar national identity in Dobruja began to emerge in the last quarter of the 19th century.<ref>[http://www.tatar.ro Romanian Tatars' Site]</ref> When [[Ismail Gasprinski]], considered by many to be the father of Crimean Tatar nationalism, visited [[Constanţa|Köstence]] ([[Constanţa]]) in 1895 he discovered his newspaper ''Tercüman'' was already in wide circulation. However, it was the poet [[Mehmet Niyazi]] who is most credited with spreading nationalist ideas among the Tatars of Dobruja. In the wake of the fall of the [[Crimean Tatars|Crimean Tatar]] government, Dobruja became the foremost place of refuge for Tatars from Crimea. Many of these refugees were inspired to join the [[Prometheism|Prometheus movement]] in Europe which aimed for the independence of Soviet nationalities. During this period Mustecip Hacı Fazıl (later took the surname Ulkusal) was the leader of community in Dobruja. In 1918, when he was 19 he went to Crimea to teach in Tatar schools and published the first Tatar journal in Dobruja, ''Emel'' from 1930 to 1940. He and other nationalists protested Tatar emigration from Dobruja to Turkey, believing resettlement in [[Crimea]] was preferable.
In the 1920s Dobruja persisted as the primary destination for refugees escaping the Soviets. The Tatars were relatively free to organize politically and publish journals founded on nationalist ideas. During [[World War II]] many Tatars escaped from [[Crimea]] and took refugee with Crimean Tatar families in Dobruja who were subsequently punished harshly by [[Communist Romania]]. The refugees who attempted escape by sea were attacked by Red Army aircraft, while those who followed land routes through [[Moldavia]] managed to reach Dobruja before the Red Army captured and deported most of them to Siberia on May 18, 1944. Necip Hacı Fazıl, the leader of the smuggling committee was executed and his brother Müstecip Hacı Fazıl fled to Turkey.
==Developments Post-WWII==
In 1940 [[Southern Dobruja]] was given to Bulgaria and by 1977 an estimated number of 23,000 Tatars were living in Romania. According to Nermin Eren that number increased to around 40,000 by the 1990s. In 2005 The [[Democratic Union of Turkish-Muslim Tatars of Romania]] claimed that there are 50,000 Tatars in Romania, believing the census estimate is artificially low because most Tatars identified themselves as Turks. Nermin Eren also estimated the number of Tatars in Bulgaria to be around 20,000 in 1990s. The Bulgarian sources estimate it to be around 6,000, though they are aware that most Tatars intermarry Turks or identify themselves as Turks. Between 1947-1957 Tatar schools began operating in Romania and in 1955 a special alphabet was created for the Tatar community. In 1990 the Democratic Union of Muslim Tatar-Turks was established. Currently Romania respects the minority rights of Tatars and does not follow any policy of [[Romanianization]].
==Subgroups==
===Crimean Tatars=== [[Crimean Tatars]] were brought to Dobruja by the Ottomans following the increasing power of the Russians in the region and its annexation of Crimea in 1783. However, after the independence of Romania in 1877-1878, between 80,000 and 100,000 Crimean Tatars moved to [[Anatolia]], a migration which continued afterwards. As such, the number of Tatars in [[Northern Dobruja]] decreased from 21% in 1880 to 5.6% in 1912. In 2002, they formed 2.4% of the population.
===Nogais=== The [[Nogais|Nogai]] component of the Tatar population are not separately enumerated in Romanian censuses. Most have emigrated to [[Turkey]] but it is estimated that a few thousand Nogais still live in Dobruja, notably in the town of [[Mihail Kogălniceanu, Constanța|Mihail Kogălniceanu]] (Karamurat) and villages of [[Lumina, Constanța|Lumina]] (Kocali), [[Medgidia|Valea Dacilor]] (Hendekkarakuyusu) and [[Cobadin]] (Kubadin).
==Localities with the highest Tatar population percentage== *Constanța County **[[Ciocârlia, Constanța|Ciocârlia]] — 11.18% **[[Valu lui Traian]] — 9.81% **[[Techirghiol]] — 9.22% **[[Independența, Constanța|Independența]] — 8.68% **[[Comana, Constanța|Comana]] — 8.37% **[[Medgidia]] — 8.07% **[[23 August, Constanța|23 August]] — 7.89% **[[Mereni, Constanța|Mereni]] — 7.85% **[[Topraisar]] — 6.48% **[[Agigea]] — 6.39% **[[Murfatlar]] — 5.5% **[[Cobadin]] — 4.86% **[[Amzacea]] — 4.71% **[[Grădina]] — 4.47% **[[Tuzla, Constanța|Tuzla]] — 4.38% **[[Eforie]] — 3.55% **[[Castelu]] — 3.37% **[[Mangalia]] — 3.25% **[[Mihail Kogălniceanu, Constanța|Mihail Kogălniceanu]] — 3.23% **[[Ovidiu]] — 3.01% **[[Lumina, Constanța|Lumina]] — 2.98% **[[Limanu]] — 2.85% **[[Siliștea, Constanța|Siliștea]] — 2.69% **[[Constanța]] — 2.59% **[[Albești, Constanța|Albești]] — 2.39% **[[Bărăganu]] — 1.7% **[[Cumpăna]] — 1.41% **[[Pecineaga]] — 1.41%
==See also== *[[Democratic Union of Turkish-Muslim Tatars of Romania]], a political party representing Tatars in Romania *[[Islam in Romania]]

{{no sources|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox award | name = World Environment Day Awards | current_awards = | image = | imagesize = | caption = | description = Excellence in Environmental Sustainability | presenter = [[United Nations Association of Australia|UNAA]] | country = [[Australia]] | location = [[Melbourne]] | year = 2000 | year2 = | website = [http://www.unaavictoria.org.au/pages/awards-program/world-environment-day-awards.php World Environment Day Awards] }}
The '''World Environment Day Awards''' are presented annually by the [[United Nations Association of Australia]] in support of the [[United Nations Environment Programme]]’s World Environment Day. The awards recognise the innovative and outstanding programs and initiatives from across Australia, and the important work of Australian environmental leaders. The annual awards program invites nominations from individuals, organisations, businesses, local councils, school, journalists and community groups whose work serves to protect, manage or restore Australia’s natural heritage. The awards aim to raise awareness about key environmental issues and challenges, and to inspire and motivate individuals, organisations and businesses to take positive steps towards sustainability and environmental excellence in their homes, school, communities and workplaces.
==Award Categories==
Current Award categories are open to a variety of nominees depending on the award, including businesses, local governments, community organisations, individuals, school and the media. The award categories have been expanded in scope and number since the awards founding in 2000, including the most recent addition of the Peter Szental Award for Sustainability Entrepreneurship, which recognises success in commercialising new sustainability solutions, demonstrating new business models and influencing mainstream thinking.
* WSP Lincolne Scott Sustainability Leadership Award * Peter Szental Award for Sustainability Entrepreneurship * Virgin Blue Business Awards * Department of Sustainability and Environment Biodiversity Award * Green Building Award * Local Government Awards * Excellence in Sustainable Water Management * Environmental Schools Award * Sustainability Education Award * Excellence in Marine and Coastal Management Award * Media Award for Environmental Reporting * Community Award * Individual Award
In 2011 the new Peter Szental Award for Sustainability Entrepreneurship recognizes businesses that have been outstanding in commercializing new sustainability solutions, demonstrating new business models and influencing mainstream thinking.
==Theme==
Each year the Awards carry a theme to coincide with the yearly theme of the United Nations Environment Programme. In 2011, the awards coincide with the International Year of Forests which raises awareness for the conservation, sustainable development, and sustainable management of forests and their inhabitants. The UNEP World Environment Day theme 'Forests: Nature at Your Service' has been declared in support of 2011 the International Year of Forests.
==Past Recipients==
Past recipients include; Darebin Council, National Australian Bank, Bond University and the Northern Gulf Resource Management Group.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.unaavictoria.org.au/pages/awards-program/world-environment-day-awards.php World environment Day Awards] * [http://www.unaavictoria.org.au/pages/home.php United Nations Association of Australia - Victorian Division] * [https://www.un.org/esa/forests/index.html/ United Nations Forum on Forests] * [http://www.unep.org/forests/ United Nations Environment Programme]
[[Category:Environmental awards]] [[Category:Awards established in 2000]]

[[File:Odeyele ayodeji with nigeria soldier and a friend from east.jpg|thumb|Nigerian youth soldier and friends]]
'''Youth in Nigeria''' includes citizens of the Federal Republic of [[Nigeria]] aged 18–35 years.<ref name="Youth Policy">{{cite web|title=Nigeria 2009 National Youth Policy https://www.k4health.org/toolkits/youthpolicy/nigeria-national-youth-policy-and-strategic-plan-action}}</ref> Variance in chronologies are used in defining [[youth]] and are addressed by members of the state in accordance to their particular society.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Furlong|first1=Andy|title=Youth Studies An introduction|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415564793}}</ref> Nigeria is the most populous country in [[Africa]] with one of the largest populations of youth in the world, comprising 33,652,424 members. Excessive mortality from [[HIV/AIDS]] results in low life expectancy in Nigeria. As a result, the median age is 17.9.<ref name="World Factbook">{{cite book|title=The CIA World Factbook 2014|date=2013|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing, Inc|isbn=9781626360730}}</ref>
Chief Olusegun Obasanjo, formerly the President of Nigeria from 1999 until 2007, believes that identifying and addressing issues that would enhance the lives of the youth would improve overall national development. He has stated that, "Youth constitute Nigeria's only hope for a real future". The Nigerian government characterizes youth as ambitious, enthusiastic, energetic and promising. They are considered vulnerable in society because of the rapid pace of change they experience at this time in their lives.<ref name="Youth Policy"/> A National Youth Development Policy was created and designed to advocate for youth and youth development. The policy views youth welfare as vital to the Nigerian nation and its socioeconomic development. This policy is seen as a youth participation project, versus a project identifying problems and needs.<ref name="Youth Policy"/>
==National Youth Policy of the Federal Republic of Nigeria== The 2009 National Youth Policy recognizes 5 priority areas that need to be addressed to enhance youth lives. These include the impact of globalization, access and use of communication technology, the impact of [[Sexually transmitted disease|STD]]s and HIV/AIDS, intergenerational issues in an aging society, and youth perpetrators and victims of armed conflict.<ref name="Youth Policy"/> The 2009 National Youth Policy is guided by several national and international policy initiatives, including National Policies for education, gender, health, population for sustainable development, and the National Economic Empowerment Development Strategy (NEEDS). The [[Millennium Development Goals]], the [[African Youth Charter]], and other international agreements further guide the policy goals found in the document.<ref name="Youth Policy"/>
[[File:Women for health (7139243509).jpg|thumb|left|Women for health training to support girls and women to train as health workers in northern Nigeria by 2016, providing support to meet entry standards.]] National Youth Policy prioritizes the difficulties women have faced throughout history. Some women experience less occupational opportunity, physical violence and abuse, and labor exploitation. They suffer negative consequences from teenage marriages and pregnancies. The policy seeks to protect their rights and promote female youths' interests and goals. By empowering females, restoring their dignity, establishing programs to end gender-based discrimination and promoting the rights, Nigerian youth policy places emphasis on the needs of young women.<ref name="Youth Policy"/>
The National Youth Policy has adopted a program for youth that are disabled. The Federal Republic of Nigeria believes that persons with disabilities have rights that should be protected by the government. The program promotes awareness of struggles that the disabled face, removing negative attitudes, while empowering the young men and women with disabilities.<ref name="Youth Policy"/>
==National Youth Council of Nigeria (NYCN)== The [[National Youth Council of Nigeria]] (NYCN) was founded in 1964 to be the voice and the umbrella organization for youth organizations in the country. The Youth Council is non‐governmental, non‐partisan, and not‐for‐profit organization. The council comprises the National Executive Committee (NEC) of 23‐ members. The NEC members are democratically elected from their respective state chapters and its affiliated voluntary youth organizations. The National Youth Council of Nigeria is a major stakeholder in the implementation of the National Youth Policy, As an umbrella organization for youth NGOs, and youth organizations across the country the NYCN pursues democratic norms at all times, embrace the principles of accountability and transparency in all its conduct, and initiate and execute activities that are in consonance with the goals of the National Youth Policy. <ref>http://www.youthpolicy.org/national/Nigeria_2009_National_Youth_Policy.pdf</ref>
==Family formation== Most Nigerians live in extended large families with separate living quarters. A Nigerian child may be breastfed until the age of 2. Mothers believe there is a bond created between mother and child by [[breastfeeding]]. Educating children is regarded as a community responsibility in some ethnic groups.<ref name="World Trade Press">{{cite book|title=Nigeria Society and Culture|date=2010|publisher=World Trade Press}}</ref> [[Parenting styles]] differ among cultures in Nigeria. Nigerian children adapt to one of three roles: authoritarian, authoritative, or permissive, depending on their culture.<ref name="World Trade Press"/>
Both boys and girls learn to be responsible and hard-working at age 5.<ref name="Esther"/> Boys contribute to routine tasks outside the home such as helping with the livestock, and helping in the fields. Girls contribute inside the home by cooking and cleaning. Elders tend to value boys higher than girls for their physical abilities and their [[ancestry]]. First, fifth, tenth, and fifteenth birthdays are marked by a large gathering for socializing and food and drink consumption as a traditional celebration.<ref name="World Trade Press"/><ref name="Esther">{{cite journal|last1=Akinsola|first1=Esther|title=Cultural Variation in Parenting Styles in the majority World Evidences From Nigeria and Cameroon}}</ref>
Nigerian [[urban area|urban]] youth develop romantic relationships that are kept a secret. Urban Nigerians are increasingly accepting meeting publicly; romantic relationships often lead to marriage. [[Cohabitation]] in urban areas is increasingly accepted prior to marriage while a romantic couple saves money to marry.<ref name="Esther"/>
Marriage is a [[coming of age]] practice among some ethnic groups. The legal minimum age to marry is 18 in most regions. Coming of age practices vary among different cultures. The [[Tiv people]] perform a ritual by marking a girl's abdomen with four incisions to make sure they are capable of conceiving a child. The Okrika Tribe hold ceremonies to mark the stage when girls are ready for marriage. These girls are painted and judged by characteristics such as beauty, grace and [[chastity]]. The girls then run a race with young men chasing them. [[Muslim]] people arrange marriages for their daughters, placing the male's family finances as an influential factor when choosing her husband. Girls are expected to marry soon after finishing school.<ref name="Esther"/>
==Education== Educating youth in Nigeria is prioritized with the goal of reducing [[poverty]], inequality, and overall increasing economic growth.<ref name="Worldbank">{{cite web|website=data.worldbank.org/country/nigeria}}</ref> Youth in Nigeria school system consists of six years of primary education, three years of junior secondary, three years of senior secondary, and four years of tertiary education.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mayfield|first1=Merry|title=Cultural Literacy and African Education|date=1989}}</ref> Primary school completion rates are 93% for males, and 91% for females.<ref name="Worldbank"/>
It is a requirement for every child in Nigeria to receive a minimum of nine years of free education. The government's dominant role with funding provides funds from the Universal Basic Education Commission (UBEC), and Education Trust Fund (ETF). Some of the problems Nigerian youth face in education are unbiased access to junior secondary, and senior secondary education for the poor, and the need to adjust the school curriculum to focus on the transition from school to [[labour market|labour economics]].<ref name="Worldbank"/> The National Youth Policy has implemented a variety of focuses in hopes to improve overall quality of education. These focal points include: development of critical fields of knowledge in applied science and technology, technical skills, vocational skills in agriculture, and promotion of the use of Information and Communication Technology (ICT).<ref name="Youth Policy"/>
The policy developed leadership roles and life training skills which seek to keep youth focused on education, politics and overall youth agency. The youth are encouraged to partake in a variety of programs including: gang related violence prevention programs, Extra-curricular competitive and recreational game activities through organizations, and a student union was launched encouraging leadership roles for youth and democratic culture.<ref name="Youth Policy"/>
==Labor and employment== Individuals in Nigeria can legally work when they are 15 years old.<ref name="World Trade Press"/> Data on youth employment in Nigeria are scarce due to underresourced agencies responsible for their collection. Eleven million youth unemployment in Nigeria were believed to be unemployed in 2012.<ref name=Akande>{{cite web|last1=Akande|first1=Tunji|title=Youth Unemployment in Nigeria: A Situation Analysis|url=http://www.brookings.edu/blogs/africa-in-focus/posts/2014/09/23-youth-unemployment-nigeria-akande|website=Brookings Institution}}</ref>
==Health risks== Nigerian youth have experienced increasing rates of [[sexually transmitted diseases]] (STD's) and [[HIV/AIDS]]. Prevalence of female youth STD contraction is 17.2%.<ref name="Ayo">{{cite journal|last1=Adebowale |first1=Ayo|last2= Titiloye|first2= Musibau|last3=Fagbamigbe|first3= Adeniyi|last4=Akinyemi|first4=Odunaya|title=Statistical modeling of social risk factors for sexually transmitted diseases among female youths in Nigeria|date= 2013}}</ref> HIV/AIDS prevalence among all youth is 5.2%, compared to the national prevalence at 4.4%.The Federal Government of Nigeria National Youth Policy attempts to mitigate prevalence by providing care, treatment and support for infected young people. In doing so, government promotes prevention activities through risk reduction, abstinence, and condom use.<ref name="Youth Policy"/>
STD and HIV/AIDS contraction can cause serious, permanent health issues, infertility, death and social consequences such as social exclusion. Many social factors contribute to the rates of contraction.<ref name="Ayo"/> Advancements in [[information communication technology]] expose youth to a variety of values and ways of thinking which differ from their elder generations.<ref name="Youth Policy"/> Cultural [[norm (social)|norm]]s serve as barriers to protect themselves in many cultures. [[Condom]] use is not a common practice.<ref name="Ayo"/>
Infection rates among youth vary according to gender, region, education, marital status, and other factors. Gender norms constrain youth women from controlling their reproductive and sexual lives. The highest rates of infection happen in the north-central part of the country (with Benue State having the highest prevalence rate), lowest in the Northeast. Urban areas have the higher rates than rural places of residency. Youth with little or no education compromised 1.3% of infected youth, in contrast to higher levels of education whose rates were 4.7%. Prevalence of contraction was higher among youth who had never been married at 2.6%, in contrast to those who were married, 1.8%. [[Premarital sex]] is common, even though it is considered a [[taboo]] in many ethnic groups. It is common in urban areas for inter-ethnic dating to occur, though inter-religious dating does not occur.<ref name="Esther"/> Youth who had previous education and testing of HIV/AIDS had higher rates of STD contraction in contrast to those who had no awareness of HIV/AIDS.<ref name="Youth Policy"/>
==Suffrage== Nigerian youth have the right to [[vote]] in political elections at 18 years of age.<ref>{{cite web|website=www.youth Policy.org}}</ref> Nigerian youth are campaigning for reduction in age qualification for political position with the [[Not Too Young To Run]] bill, which seeks to reduce the age too run for President from 40years to 30years; Governor 35 to 30, Senate 35 to 30, House of Representatives 30 to 25 and State of Assembly 30 to 25.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Olanrewaju|first1=Eweniyi|title=The Nigerian Senate Finally Passes The 'Not Too Young To Run' Bill|url=http://www.konbini.com/ng/lifestyle/the-nigerian-senate-finally-passes-the-not-too-young-to-run-bill/|accessdate=24 December 2017|publisher=Konbini|date=July 27, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=YOUTH INITIATIVE FOR ADVOCACY, GROWTH & ADVANCEMENT|first1=YIAGA|title=#NotTooYoungToRun|url=http://yiaga.org/nottooyoungtorun/the-bill/|website=www.yiaga.org|publisher=YOUTH INITIATIVE FOR ADVOCACY, GROWTH & ADVANCEMENT|accessdate=24 December 2017}}</ref>
==Youth in armed conflict== Since the [[Post Cold War era]], oil based revenues and its disbursements in the [[Niger Delta]] region has led to massive protests and violence among youth. Young people have engaged in attacks against oil firms and Nigerian militants, hostage taking and hijacking oil workers, youth militancy, vandalizing oil pipelines, and detonating bombs.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ukkiwo|first1=U|title=From Pirates to Milirtants: a Historical Perspective on Anti-state and Anti-oil company mobalisation among the Ijaw of Warri, Western Niger Delta|journal=African Affairs|volume=106|issue=425|pages=587–610}}</ref> Tension in the public has caused conflict among minority and majority groups which has crippled national and social development.<ref name="Arowosegbe">{{cite journal|last1=Arowosegbe|first1=Jeremiah|title=Violence and National Development in Nigeria: The Political Economy of Youth Restiveness in the Niger Delta|journal=Review of African Political Economy|doi=10.1080/03056240903346178}}</ref> The youth's participation in violence is their way of expressing feelings of [[marginalization]] and that their voices are not heard in competing for resources.<ref name="Arowosegbe"/>
==See also== [[Youwin!|YouWin]]
==Sources== {{Reflist}}
{{Human rights in Nigeria}} [[Category:Nigerian society]] [[Category:Nigerian people]] [[Category:Youth in Nigeria| ]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Ziona |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1945|7|21|df=y}} |birth_place = Baktawng village, [[Mizoram]], India |spouse = 39 |parents = |children = 94 |known_for = Fathering the largest living family |employer = }} '''Ziona''' (/zai'awna/) (often misnamed in the non-native media as '''Ziona Chana'''; born July 21, 1945)<ref name=Marry>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/guwahati/Mizoram-man-with-39-wives-raring-to-marry-again/articleshow/21260695.cms|title=Mizoram man with 39 wives raring to marry again|date=23 July 2013|newspaper=The Times of India}}</ref><ref name= Gregory>{{Cite news|last= Gregory |first=Andrew |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/worlds-largest-family-with-181-members-86797|title=World's largest family with 181 members live in 100-room, four-storey house in India|date=21 October 2011 |newspaper=The Mirror}}</ref> is the leader of ''Chana páwl'', a [[Christian]] sect formed in June 1942, which survives in the mountains of [[Mizoram]] [[States and Union Territories of India|state of India]], sharing borders with [[Bangladesh]] and [[Myanmar]].<ref name=Record>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/22/us-india-family-idUSTRE71L4VH20110222|title=Man has 39 wives, nearly 100 children|date=22 February 2011|publisher=Reuters}}</ref> He is known for holding a world record as the head of the "world's largest existing family" with 39 wives, 94 children, 14 daughters-in-law and 33 grandchildren, 180 in total and counting. The family is now living in Baktawng village, Mizoram, India.<ref name=Academy>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldrecordacademy.com/society/biggest_family_Ziona_Chana_has_39_wifes_and_94_children_a_world_record_112126.html|title=Family: Ziona Chana has 39 wifes and 94 children: a world record (Video)|publisher=Worldrecord Academy}}</ref> Ziona was featured in ''[[Ripley's Believe It or Not!]]'' top 11 strangest stories for the year 2011,<ref name=Story>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2720021.ece|title=Indian with 39 wives, 94 kids is the strangest story of 2011|date=16 December 2011|newspaper=The Hindu}}</ref> and in 2013's Ripley Believe It or Not book 9. He is proud of and fortunate to be head of such a large family.<ref name= Gregory/><ref name="Inc.2013"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Reviews in Brief|url= http://www.ripleys.com/weird/inside-ripleys-world/reviews-in-brief/|work=Ripley's Believe It or Not|publisher=Ripley Entertainment Inc.|date=11 November 2012}}</ref>
==Religious faith== Ziona is chief of the group known as "Chana Pawl", which was established by his father.<ref name=Record>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/22/us-india-family-idUSTRE71L4VH20110222|title=Man has 39 wives, nearly 100 children|date=22 February 2011|publisher=Reuters}}</ref> The sect practices [[polygamy]].<ref name="Inc.2013"/> Chana sect followers claim that its origin is traced to the [[Bible]]'s Revelation Chapter 20 to "Kum Sang Rorel" or the rule of 1,000 years by [[Jesus Christ]] on Earth.<ref name=Mizo>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-mizo-man-has-39-wives-94-children-33-grandchildren-1510550|title=Mizo man has 39 wives, 94 children, 33 grandchildren|date=20 February 2011|publisher=DNA India}}</ref> The sect was originally named ''Khuangtuaha Pawl'', after the founder Khuangtuaha. He founded it on 12 June 1942, when its disciples were removed from Hmawngkawn village by the headman of the village for propagating a [[theology]] considered "wrong and dangerous".<ref name=Mizo>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-mizo-man-has-39-wives-94-children-33-grandchildren-1510550|title=Mizo man has 39 wives, 94 children, 33 grandchildren|date=20 February 2011|publisher=DNA India}}</ref> The sect celebrates its founding day as "Bawkte Kut" or the festival of the hut on June 12 every year. Members of the Chana sect number about 2,000 who reside in the Baktawng Tlangnuam village.<ref name=Marry>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/guwahati/Mizoram-man-with-39-wives-raring-to-marry-again/articleshow/21260695.cms|title=Mizoram man with 39 wives raring to marry again|date=23 July 2013|newspaper=The Times of India}}</ref>
==Family life== Ziona hails from the village of Baktawng in central [[Serchhip district]], which is {{Convert|100|km}} to the south of [[Aizawl]], the capital of Mizoram.<ref name=Marry/> He was born on 21 July 1945.<ref name=Marry/> He was married at the age of 17 to Zathiangi, his first wife, who was older than him by three years. She now controls the household activities of the family with strict discipline and is proud that everyone in the family respects her role.<ref name= Gregory/> Ten of his wives he married in the span of one year.<ref name="Inc.2013">{{cite book|author=Ripley's Entertainment Inc.|title=Ripley's Special Edition 2014|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LVRrAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA42|date=27 August 2013|publisher=Scholastic|isbn=978-0-545-62260-8|pages=42–}}</ref>
Ziona has built a four-storied mansion, a concrete structure, which appears like a boarding house, to accommodate his large family.<ref name= Gregory/> The house is called the "''Chhuan Thar Run''" or the House of the New Generation and is located in the mountainous village of Baktawng.<ref name=Academy/> There is also a 'Khualbuk' or a guesthouse to accommodate visitors coming to the village.<ref name=Marry/> Ziona has a double bedroom in the ground floor of this mansion and his wives take turns to sleep with him according to a roster. His younger wives stay close to his room on the same floor and there are always seven to eight wives attending to his needs during the day. All older wives live in the dormitories on the first floor of the mansion, while his younger wives live on the ground floor. His wives claim that there is no rivalry among them.<ref name= Gregory/><ref name=Record/><ref name=Academy/> All his wives claim to love him. His 40th wife is Madam Siamthangi who is proud to be Ziona's wife even though he is much older than her. She is 30 years old (as of 2012) and has a five-year-old daughter by him. Of his 39 wives, 22 are below the age of 40 and they get a week to spend with him.<ref name=Koh>{{Cite news|last=Koh|first= Maureen |url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne%2BNews/Asia/Story/A1Story20120220-329009.html|title=Wife No.39 is 'luckiest woman in the world'|date=21 February 2012|newspaper=Asiaone}}</ref> He has 26 sons-in-law and his daughters live separately with their families. He says that he has named all his children and grandchildren and he remembers the names of every member of his family.<ref name=Koh/>
Ziona's family is self-reliant, growing crops for their food requirements. He has also established a school for his children, and his younger brother looks after its functioning. Though teaching in the school is based on a curriculum prescribed by the government, he has added some subjects specific to his Chana sect. He does not seek any assistance from the government.<ref name=Eat>{{Cite news|url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne%2BNews/Asia/Story/A1Story20120220-329009/2.html|title=They eat 100kg of rice a day|newspaper=Asiaone}}</ref>
Ziona's wives do the cooking, and his daughters attend to cleaning of the house and take care of washing laundry. Men of the family attend to livestock rearing, agriculture ([[jhum cultivation]]), small cottage industries of wood furniture (carpentry), aluminum utensil making, and so forth.<ref name=Marry>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/guwahati/Mizoram-man-with-39-wives-raring-to-marry-again/articleshow/21260695.cms|title=Mizoram man with 39 wives raring to marry again|date=23 July 2013|newspaper=The Times of India}}</ref><ref name=Record/><ref name=Koh/>
Daily family life in his house begins at 5.50 AM when all family members assemble for prayers and thereafter daily duties are assigned. Prayers and meals are held in a large hall in the mansion. Dinner is served from 4 to 6 PM in the order of age, and the day comes to a close with everyone retiring for the night by 9PM when the lights are switched off.<ref name=Eat/>
An enormous amount of food is prepared to feed the family: {{convert|220|lb}} of rice, {{convert|132|lb}} of potatoes and 39 chickens.<ref name=Record/><ref name=Academy/><ref name="Inc.2013"/>{{clarify |date=August 2016 |reason= per what amount of time?}}
Ziona's 68th birthday was celebrated on 21 July 2013 with 150 guests.<ref name=Marry/>
''Ripley's Believe It or Not!'', while recording Ziona's family as the largest living family in the world, observed: "It's a safe bet that Ziona Chana would not be impressed watching ''19 Kids and Counting'' or ''Sister Wives''. The 66-year-old Indian man has 39 wives, 94 children and 33 grandchildren."<ref name=Story/>
Ziona is interested in having more wives, even from the United States.<ref name=Academy/>
